reviewText:
I have always enjoyed steath games and I am really enjoying Styx. I agree with the other positive reviews that if you like stealth games then get Styx Master of Shadows. Don't expect to be going around fighting all the time, thats not what the game is about. You are a 3 foot tall goblin with a dagger not a big badass warrior. It's a stealth game not an action game. That doesn't mean Styx isn't deadly. He is skilled at killing enemy after enemy from the shadows. Sneaking up on your enemies for a kill or avoiding them all together is the best way to play the game.

Styx is a great character with a lot of personality. It's fun being Styx. The stealth works well and the abilities you earn add to the choices you have when making your way to the next objective.. The problems people had with ledge detection and climbing when the game was released have been patched so that is not a problem any more.

I think the graphics are good, not the best ever but they get the job done for sure. The environments and characters are detailed, the lighting is pretty good. I lowered the brightness to make the dark feel dark. The world you traverse is big and there are lots of different paths to discover as you explore the environment. The background music fits the mood and the voice over is good.

If I had to fault the game at all I would say they should add an animation of Styx crawling over the edge of ledges and make it so you can move to the next section of the ledge at a corner. Also, they could improve some of the character animations for Styx and the NPC's to look and feel more natural.


EDIT : When I got to the end of the game, almost 30 hrs, the developer forces you to fight these clones and it does not fit everything you did to get to that point. Its a stealth game not a slasher button masher WTF ! I am really disappointed in this design choice. I am leaving the positive review but just barely positive, just know that If I had to rate it I would drop it from an 8 to a 6 because of this stupidity. I will probably just uninstall it now. I may avoid part 2 as well. The guy who thought this was a good idea should be fired.

reviewText:
I have played this game a lot more than my hours would indicate, on someone else's copy, approximately 20 hours when writing this.

This is an excellent stealth game in so many ways. The graphics is not overly impressive but functional and runs very smoothly at a solid 60 fps on a decent computer. The story is good and it's got the most original protagonist you've seen in a long time, the atmosphere is excellent and you really start to feel for the little goblin. But the game mechanics is where this game really shines. This is made for gamers by gamers, a super smooth engine that just does things right. The gaming media basically gave it mediocre scores because it was not Assassins Creed, but the critics failed to recognize what a brilliantly balanced game this is. It's challenging yet hardly ever annoying. There are many little details that are just right, like you can save anywhere you want and very solid controls. Personally I prefer this game over Dishonored, mostly because of the atmosphere and level design.

Also, the so called game breaking bug" isn't. It is extremely rare that it happens
recommended: and as long as you keep more than one save game you are safe so don't freak out about that.\n\nFor fans of fantasy stealth games this title is well worth a buy at full price and a steal on a sale."

reviewText:
Styx is an amazing stealth game that requires patience and cunning to play.

Summary:
Choose your own path in a stealthy endeavor to defeat the guards and obtain treasure for your trophy room.
Each room brings a puzzle of its own as you choose how to deal with the guards. You are in trouble if you are caught but you can use powers to help you in most situations. There are some minor issues in regards to map and dropping to a ledge but the pros heavily outweigh the cons.

Pros:
- Choose your own path! You decide how you want to get where you have to go
- You are not spoon-fed the paths. If you want to sneak around then take risks and discover the paths
- Take the time to study the guards, know their paths and use to that to your advantage. Each different room seems like its own puzzle
- Powers help you along but are not the main focus as they cost a lot and potions are tough to find
- Hideout at the end of every level where you upgrade and refill on everything
- If you get caught, you will likely die. This is good in the sense that it motivates you to not get caught but challenging to those who may be coming from an assassins creed style of play where battles are welcome

Cons:
- The map is a little difficult to get used to as it is just a blue print of the area with no layers for floors, just an overtop view where you only see the topmost floor and the lower floors in the gaps. Keep track of where you are or you will likely end up chasing your own tail
- The vision does not seem as helpful as I thought it would be. Everything just gets lit and its too bright to discern from highlighted objects and the walls
- Might be getting picky here but you cannot transfer sideways to another ledge
- The drop to ledge mechanism could use some work. It does not seem guaranteed that you will catch the ledge when walking slow to the edge so it could make for some rage moments
- The character seems a bit vulgar at times, swearing unnecessarily to make his point. I would say leaning towards neutral evil.

reviewText: Styx feels like a hodgepodge of Dishonored, Assassin's Creed, and Splinter Cell except it does all the wrong things. On the surface, the game is gorgeous and the protagonist is a pretty cool and interesting dude. You'll soon discover that things like light-based detection and ragdoll physics just aren't up to snuff with any modern or old stealth game.\n\nThe whole thing feels pretty rushed beyond the first couple of missions. Once you've finally unlocked the last set of equipment, don't expect any further interesting interaction than what you can do immediately. Static light sources and some strange, unspoken alliance between guards and monsters are only some of the lazy design choices ahead of you.

reviewText:
Look all I can say about this game is that Everything Theif 4 was meant to be, is this game. Only difference is that your a squirmy goblin. The items are simple, the bad guys are simple (hide in shadows attack out of sight). You can also stuff bodies in area's like a chest ect to hide evidence which is a neat little idea.

This is really fun game, a bit simple on the outside but the game itself masters wonderfully in the basic principles of a stealth game something which assasins creed and Theif 4 fail to do considerbly. Dishonored comes close to this game in being more stealthy but without as many choices to kill your enemies. Killing is something I was kind of suprised they did not have a blackjack like theif, as blood stains from using a cutting weapon was a great little addition in stealth games for bad guys to notice someone is around. Minor but somewhat important if you want to be above the rest in stealth games.

The downside I felt was the lack of intergration of Orcs and Men. The first video game with greenskins which even though are seperate stories and completly different combat/years apart, having them linked to bring the unique world more depth would of helped a great deal.

Secondly  I dislike the save system, its like the old school save system. Usually if you play harder difficulties like me, and die the save takes you back way too far in the game and have to repeat (I usually just quit and cant be bothered repeating 15 minutes of hard work). Have not checked if there is quick save yet but does not seem to be. That said, you should save regularly if you get this game.

Also don't listen to those fools talking about objects making too much noise, your character jumps like a pogo stick and can prety much avoid anything, grappling like assasins creed almost but without the prince of persia feel.

Overall this is a great game, and the price is well within acceptable purchase range. If your a stealth fan you will love it; If your a call of duty/Assasins Creed fan you probally will hate it cause its a proper stealth game not a smash and grab the loot game. Also Skyrim Fans may enjoy this, if you were a fan of the stealth skill tree.

reviewText: Styx. Where do I start... Well, lets start with him actually. Styx is a strangely lovable little goblin, who has a knack for stealth, quick hands, and is good with his beloved dagger. He has a bit of a mouth on him, which I don't care for, and honestly seems unessasary. The stealth mechanics in this game are honestly some of the best I've ever played. You aren't invisible when you go into the shadows, just harder to see. You can't get away from enemies very well, since you're only a little guy, and you are just good enough in combat to fend off a lone attacker. So yes, this game is all about stealth. Now the levels. The levels are pretty dang big, and give you a mulitude of options to take into consideration when polaying them out. Something I really love is the difficulty of the game. I'm playing on normal right now, (there are two harder modes above that) and I've gotten stuck tons of times. Not stuck as in I didn't know where to go, but stuck as in I didn't know how to proceed. I was hiding under a table for fifteen minutes once trying to figure out the best way to get away from the guards. It's a wonderfully made game, lovely graphics, and fantastic mechanics. I'd say it gets a high rating of 8.5/10.

reviewText:
Styx: Master of Shadows is old school stealth through and through. With impeccable level design, smooth controls, a dastardly yet likeable protagonist and a surprisingly enthralling storyline, it's a great game thats rock hard to play right but rewards greatly those who do. Its also marvellously fun to play.

You are the game's namesake, Styx, a little goblin who's been caught trying to access an important magical power source, the 'Heart of the Tree'. You start the story being interrogated by the Humans and, through flashbacks, are able to tell them how you managed to make it so far undetected. The story sounds like a simple heist and uncovering-of-a-consiparacy tale though it twists and turns in ways that are surprisingly effective at throwing off any pre-conceptions.

The gameplay is very Thief-like, except its obviously third person rather than first. It lessens the immersion factor slightly but you'll not really notice, as you sneak around massive labyrinthine complexes completing primary and secondary objectives, stealing the many golden coins serving as the game's main collectible and overhearing the relentlessly braindead gabble from guards and workmen. Occasionally, you may overhear of people talking of hidden stashes which you can locate and raid, often by following the person who exposed their little secret.

As you navigate the often lofty environments, there are many opportunities to find tucked away passages helping you bypass particularly busy sections that are hard to cross undetected. Compared to Dishonored, a game with a similar amount of complexity in its level design, these are not frequently found and most of the time, you'll have to sneak across the more dangerous sections using just your wits and your limited arsenal of equipment (and have a finger over F5).

Your equipment comprises of physical items such as throwing knives - perfect for distant kills and dislodging chandeliers to cause distractions or to kill the game's more resilient enemies - and magic. Magic (known as 'amber' in game) allows you to turn invisible, see things in a orange highlight and create clones. These little fellas can help you traverse areas Styx is unable to go and serve as great little distraction toys. Guards can be lured from their patrols by a clone, leaving you to sneak on by, or you can use them to mask your escape if they become alerted by turning them into smoke bombs.

The game has a degree of combat should you get caught, though it's not exactly an ideal scenario. Basically, it puts you in a position where you are locked into a duel with another, often much stronger, individual. Time it right with the left mouse button and you'll parry. Do this several more times and you'll have the option to kill them. It takes practice getting it right but the worst thing is that you can't flee from it once it happens. You either have to get it right or get killed (the latter often being the best choice, assuming you've been saving plenty - it IS a stealth game after all!)

Combat isn't the best option of covering your tracks once spotted. The system is more trouble than its worth, bringing nearly all the enemies in your vicinity running to end your sorry little life. If a body is found, the guards will be on high alert, with heightened senses and investigating susceptible hiding spots like chests, closets and underneath tables. Playing Styx well means saving often, planning your every movement across risky areas, staying in the shadows and, even within shadows, staying still when enemies move closer to you. You also need to use equipment wisely - you can only carry a maximum of three of each, even then with skill points invested.

Skill points are earnt completing objectives and performing feats. These include 'ghosting' a level, not killing anyone, completing the level within a certain time limit and collecting all the coins. They encourage different ways of playing and allow the levels to be very replayable. They are replayable to an extent but, mostly for story reasons, the latter half of them are the first ones but in reverse. It's a bit of a downer, especially since the early levels showed much promise of greater variation later on but it's a sacrifice on the story front - itself a worthy reason to pick this game up - and the game isn't harmed by it in terms of dimininishing the challenge presented to you as the game progresses. On the contrary, the new and even more lethal enemies turn up to make Styx's journey that bit harder, and areas devoid of enemies in the beginning are often full of them when you return.

Final points; the voice acting across the board is above average, and Styx's VA is fantastic. The soundtrack is also good, fitting the mood of the different (though not numerous) environments to a tee. The game supports controllers if you find the keyboard and mouse controls too cumbersome, especially for the platforming which, while perfectly serviceable with KBM, is clearly designed for a joystick in mind.

Despite a few flaws in its design, Styx: Master of Shadows delivers the goods of providing old school, hardcore stealth to the new generation. It's not quite Thief or Hitman tier but it certainly gives modern stealth-em-ups like Dishonored a run for their money. In fact, as much as I love Dishonored and the fact that it's toted as Thief's 'spiritual successor', I'd be willing to give Styx that honour instead.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Styx: Master of Shadows is old school stealth through and through. With impeccable level design, smooth controls, a dastardly yet likeable protagonist and a surprisingly enthralling storyline, it's a great game thats rock hard to play right but rewards greatly those who do. Its also marvellously fun to play.

You are the game's namesake, Styx, a little goblin who's been caught trying to access an important magical power source, the 'Heart of the Tree'. You start the story being interrogated by the Humans and, through flashbacks, are able to tell them how you managed to make it so far undetected. The story sounds like a simple heist and uncovering-of-a-consiparacy tale though it twists and turns in ways that are surprisingly effective at throwing off any pre-conceptions.

The gameplay is very Thief-like, except its obviously third person rather than first. It lessens the immersion factor slightly but you'll not really notice, as you sneak around massive labyrinthine complexes completing primary and secondary objectives, stealing the many golden coins serving as the game's main collectible and overhearing the relentlessly braindead gabble from guards and workmen. Occasionally, you may overhear of people talking of hidden stashes which you can locate and raid, often by following the person who exposed their little secret.

As you navigate the often lofty environments, there are many opportunities to find tucked away passages helping you bypass particularly busy sections that are hard to cross undetected. Compared to Dishonored, a game with a similar amount of complexity in its level design, these are not frequently found and most of the time, you'll have to sneak across the more dangerous sections using just your wits and your limited arsenal of equipment (and have a finger over F5).

Your equipment comprises of physical items such as throwing knives - perfect for distant kills and dislodging chandeliers to cause distractions or to kill the game's more resilient enemies - and magic. Magic (known as 'amber' in game) allows you to turn invisible, see things in a orange highlight and create clones. These little fellas can help you traverse areas Styx is unable to go and serve as great little distraction toys. Guards can be lured from their patrols by a clone, leaving you to sneak on by, or you can use them to mask your escape if they become alerted by turning them into smoke bombs.

The game has a degree of combat should you get caught, though it's not exactly an ideal scenario. Basically, it puts you in a position where you are locked into a duel with another, often much stronger, individual. Time it right with the left mouse button and you'll parry. Do this several more times and you'll have the option to kill them. It takes practice getting it right but the worst thing is that you can't flee from it once it happens. You either have to get it right or get killed (the latter often being the best choice, assuming you've been saving plenty - it IS a stealth game after all!)

Combat isn't the best option of covering your tracks once spotted. The system is more trouble than its worth, bringing nearly all the enemies in your vicinity running to end your sorry little life. If a body is found, the guards will be on high alert, with heightened senses and investigating susceptible hiding spots like chests, closets and underneath tables. Playing Styx well means saving often, planning your every movement across risky areas, staying in the shadows and, even within shadows, staying still when enemies move closer to you. You also need to use equipment wisely - you can only carry a maximum of three of each, even then with skill points invested.

Skill points are earnt completing objectives and performing feats. These include 'ghosting' a level, not killing anyone, completing the level within a certain time limit and collecting all the coins. They encourage different ways of playing and allow the levels to be very replayable. They are replayable to an extent but, mostly for story reasons, the latter half of them are the first ones but in reverse. It's a bit of a downer, especially since the early levels showed much promise of greater variation later on but it's a sacrifice on the story front - itself a worthy reason to pick this game up - and the game isn't harmed by it in terms of dimininishing the challenge presented to you as the game progresses. On the contrary, the new and even more lethal enemies turn up to make Styx's journey that bit harder, and areas devoid of enemies in the beginning are often full of them when you return.

Final points; the voice acting across the board is above average, and Styx's VA is fantastic. The soundtrack is also good, fitting the mood of the different (though not numerous) environments to a tee. The game supports controllers if you find the keyboard and mouse controls too cumbersome, especially for the platforming which, while perfectly serviceable with KBM, is clearly designed for a joystick in mind.

Despite a few flaws in its design, Styx: Master of Shadows delivers the goods of providing old school, hardcore stealth to the new generation. It's not quite Thief or Hitman tier but it certainly gives modern stealth-em-ups like Dishonored a run for their money. In fact, as much as I love Dishonored and the fact that it's toted as Thief's 'spiritual successor', I'd be willing to give Styx that honour instead.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Not the best of reviews, but since I saw this game was put on sale, I wanted to add my two cents on the game.


If you enjoy stealth games where little things like sounds, light levels, objects, etc. all matter in being steathy, then you will like this game.   The graphics and visuals are great, the sounds and music very enjoyable, and the degree of different play styles, are well blended together.  Obviously stealth is the safer route, but doing it completly, takes a lot of obsevations and some skill in timing plus resource managing.    The dificulty of the game was challenging, but far from impossible.   There are skills that can be leveled up to improve how they work, along with skills that improve the use of items.    There is a 'safehouse' that you can practice in and keep things that were collected.   The story itself was kind of cheesy, but it had its fair share of twists and was enjoyable.    There were some issues early on in the game with people being 'stuck' at certain spots due to some bug, but I was lucky to not have such an issue.


Overall, this is a great fantasty stealth game that can provide plenty of challenges, whether you are the rogue who sticks to the shadows, or the bold guy who goes in all stab stab stab stab.   Plenty of things to look for through out the game and each area, and IMO, its just an enjoyable game that a lot of people can pick up, and get into.    So, if you are on the fence of whether you should buy it or not, then for the price of $7.49, you ae getting a great deal.

reviewText:
I could see how this game might get a bad wrap but, if you really give this game a chance, that is you learn all the knit picky nuances of the combat system and using the climbing system, special moves and jumping around, it's a really fun stealth game. I can't stop playing even though I whisper, WTF! Quite often trying to get the timing right or when my character gets stuck inside a dead npc  or something. If you like stealth games that allow you to actually be a bad ♥♥♥, this is a great game. My dude is bad ♥♥♥ when killing from cover or death from above. I hardly use magic at all.

I really like the level design and the goblin graphic. I'm a huge goblin fan and I think they nailed the look and movement. The voice, well I doubt a goblin is 1950's gangster from philly. Overall the gameplay is really fun. I don't know if this will be a one time play through or not, but probably will.

Cons:
*Combat system is rigid, as in sometimes you can do something and seemingly other times you can't. It's not reliable until you really learn exactly how to do certain things and under what circumstances. Some things like the special moves (pulling enemies down while I'm hanging) don't work at all for me.
*AI is meh, ok. Nothing to write home about but it could be better.
*Controls are limited
*There are bugs like your character or NPC bodies getting stuck in the walls with bad clipping with ragdoll dynamics.

Ultimately, this game is 8 out of 10 in my opinion. I am glad I bought it.

reviewText:
Styx is an excellent stealth game. It reminds me of all those Tenchu games that I had a blast playing ages ago. Be aware this is a STEALTH game. You can mass murder everything, but if you have to fight two or more enemies at once you're almost certainly dead. Due to that simple fact the combat is almost non-existant, and that's a good thing.

The game should take about 20 or so hours, but as there are secondary missions plus several insignias to get for each level - no killing, ♥♥♥♥♥ing all items, etc. - and it's rather impossible to get everything in one run the incentive for replaying the levels is there.  The level design is very nice, with levels not covering huge ground, but spanning horizontally and vertically with many ways to get to mission targets.

The story is quite interesting, but the cutscenes are underwhelming, only static drawings with voiceovers. Still, the game is extremely fun and if you are a fan of stealth games then you definetely want to try Styx.

reviewText:
Let me get one thing out of the way: I am not a man of subtlety. I do my business blunt and direct. I never was much of a fan of stealth games and only started to pay attention to Styx: Master of Shadows because it has Goblins it in. Not as enemies, mind you, but as the playable protagonist. I never imagined i would enjoy this game as much as i did. To me, it is a rough diamond and a candidate for my personal list of best games of 2015.

Styx is far from a perfect game. It has some serious problems. Like the poor face textures, mediocre dialogue animations or that everything is done with a combination with 2 or 3 buttons which can lead to more than one unexpected demise.
But overall, this game has a touch to it, i cant deny it. It felt like i was playing a stealth version of Overlord II in a lince free warhammer setting. You play a sociopathic midget on his greedy quest to steal a heavily protected treasure in an ancient stone tower build around a magic tree full of supremacist humans and drug addicted hivemind elves.

The graphical design is overall nice looking. I had the impression of a solid medieval castle in its prime. The guards gave a serious knightly impression, but were fleshed out enough to fit the fantasy setting. What i like best about them is, that they curse like you expect them to. This game has crude language and  drops a pleasant amount of f-bombs. I will never forget the guard screaming after me something about my rat ♥♥♥♥ing ancestors after i smashed 3 of his comrades under a giant lamp. Not to mention the rich and spacey prison which reminded me of the torture chambers of Diablo 2.

The sound of this game is pleasantly disturbing. You ger a serious feel for stalking murder in dark corners. To the point where this game could make your spine chill. No jump scares were to be found, but it had a touch of horror game to it.
If you like classic music and violins you will have a blast. Also, hearing sounds in this game is not only a utility, but a weaponized tool. You will need it. Has a taste of chess and puzzle solving to it. In the vertical sense. With more gore.

Styx story writing and gameplay is nothing shy of a big circle jerk. In the most positive terms speaking. You start off having no idea how or why, have 2 or 3 mind ♥♥♥♥s, do a 360, get back from where you came and end where you started. Very existential and confusing. But I liked it a big deal. Your tools will help you though, and no matter how much you think you are competent, the various enemy types can rip you to smithereens in seconds if you have a slip or get unlucky. Not even with full skill trees. Precise control is mandatory and thankful to the exact physics engine, mostly granted.

Without a doubt the best Orc/Goblin focused game i played in a long and a high remark for the stealth genre overall. Not Important from Hatred could take lessons from the unarmed and armed combat abilities of this sadistic manslayer you play here. What i missed out though were woman. None were to be seen in this tower of sausage fest. Not even at the elfs. I would have enjoyed getting a stab at some elf ♥♥♥.

Excellent game. Give it an 8/10. Worth its money and more. Played the shît out of it for a whole month in these large sprawling tower sections. This may be a game with a small name, but it has a big heart. Hope to see more from Cyanide with Styx and Arkail. Recommendation Permission granted.

I really wish I could play it again for the first time.  It is definitely worth both your time and your money.\n

Styx is an excellent stealth game. It reminds me of all those Tenchu games that I had a blast playing ages ago. Be aware this is a STEALTH game. The level design is very nice, with levels not covering huge ground, but spanning horizontally and vertically with many ways to get to mission targets.

reviewText: This is stealth gaming at its purest. Lurk in the shadows, climb in the rafters, and only approach enemies when there's no one to hear them scream. The combat is unweildy, awkward, and just plain bad - and that makes it amazing. If fighting were viable, or even enjoyable, it would ruin the game's incredible tension. reviewText:
Rating: 7.5/10
Overview: Third Person Stealth

The Good:
+ Level design offers multiple pathways to any objective. You can either take a direct approach or a stealthier one depending on how well you explore the levels. Certain levels are linear while others are more open.

+ The story is interesting and offers some nice twists and turns to keep things engaging.

+ The AI finds a nice balance between realistic and fun. Rushing head first into any given room will usually result in death

+ Completing main/side objectives as well as challenges rewards you with experience which can then be used to upgrade skills back at your hideout.

+ Soundtrack

The Average:

The art style both on an artistic and technical level is pretty lacking. I wanted more variety with the environments, it feels like a wasted opportunity given the setting.

Combat" in the game is about parrying enemy attacks until you can kill them. Essentially its 'press the attack button at the right moment" over and over again. Granted this IS a stealth game so combat is a second priority but it would be nice if something better was in place. Getting caught and having to engage with the enemies feels frustrating and boring.

The second half of the game recycles the same levels that you completed in the first half.


The Bad

- The game has a ton of glitches. At first I thought it was cute but the same problems kept persisting throughout the entire game. The biggest offender is enemy guards that walk into each other causing them to end up in weird places there not suppose to be.

- Stealth games always have a difficult time with the final boss encounter and this game is no different. Given the build up of the story the final encounter is anticlimactic and frustrating.


Conclusion

Stealth is a genre that doesn't get much love from big publishers so its nice to see other smaller studios tackle the genre. This is a great stealth but obviously held back by its budget. If you love stealth games this is easily a must have game as it does so much right in regards to the gameplay mechanics.

reviewText:
Styx: Master of Shadows is a really great game and one of my favorite stealth games ever. Don't get me wrong, it's not perfect but it s worth 30 $ but i bought it 5 $ when it is on discount.

There aren't many stealth games around these days and Dishonored is really good but Styx is similar. The gameplay mechanics work really well in this game and there are some that I haven't seen in any other stealth game, such as cloning yourself and booby trapping your clone in a chest or just use it as a distraction for guards. You can even become invisible for short time spans. These things cost you amber which is basically something like mana. You can replenish it with vials you can find during the missions or pickpocket from some of the guards. But those are rare, so don't worry, you can't just walk around the whole level invisibly.

The skill system is also a good thing. It motivated me to get all the insignias and do all the side objectives in the missions, since you get bonus skill points for doing so. With them you can unlock helpful skills such as aerial kills or the aforementioned booby trapping of your clone. You can go for stealthy skills if you like to sneak through the missions or, if you're more into clearing out whole areas, you can invest in more aggressive skills. Every type of player should be able to find some skills they think are cool.

There are also different types of enemies, such as your ordinary guard, crossbowmen, knights, which have plate armor and can only be killed through poisoning or dropping chandeliers on their head, and some more that I won't spoil now. Every enemy has its weak spots and is in his way fun to kill or sneak around.

What I think is really outstanding in Styx is the environment. The level design is just awesome. There are many routes to your destination and you almost always have a choice of how to get there. In synergy with the mostly good graphics (at least good enough for me) and the great lighting effects it often led to me just stopping and looking at the beautiful environments. It's just eye candy to sneak around in the shadows avoiding the bright sun rays falling in a room through a window or climbing a vertical wall in the sunset.

Sadly the fun exploring the levels ends with the exact half of the game. After that you will be back tracked through many levels you have already seen. In most cases this isn't that bad, because there are other guards on other positions with other routes and the levels are still awesome with all the alternative routes. But I have to say that there were one or two areas that just didn't work properly backwards, which was sometimes a little annoying. Nevertheless the back tracking wasn't so bad, although I gladly would have payed 5 or 10 more bucks to just see some more of this really great level design.

The story line was okay for me. It had its suprises and pulled me through the missions and that's all I was expecting from it. The plot is told through voice acting and comic like cutscenes with mostly static pictures of which some were reused a little too often, but that's perfectly fine thinking of the price for the title. The voice acting was good and I personally liked the fact that although the story is set in a fantasy world, the characters swear a lot and talk more like you would expect from real world rogues. That added a special feeling to it and I liked it.

Overall I loved this game and though it has its flaws the whole experience is just great, because every mechanic and every element come together to form a really fun time of stealth gameplay. And since it's worth even the full 30€ in my opinion (i got it 5 dolllars), I recommend this game to every gamer who enjoys stealth games.

8.7 / 10

Bought this game on sale, was a decent purchase.  I haven't played a stealth game in a long time, now I remember why.  This game is pretty much pure stealth, if you get detected or enter combat you are almost guaranteed to get killed.  It is also obviously a port from console.  So if you don’t like stealth games, avoid at all costs.

Pros:

Graphics aren’t bad, really liked the art and design of the game.
Story is good, really kept me going to find out what was next.
Levels are well designed with lots of hidey holes and places to see.
I felt I got my money’s worth, played only the story once through and it took me a bit of time so it wasn’t too short.

Cons:

The combat is just plain terrible, a parry system, you have to parry a certain number of times and then you get to kill.
The ending was atrocious, they forced you into combat which was the worst part of the game.
I aint kidding, the very last level stunk up to high heaven.
The side missions could have used more of an indicator, I really hate trying to look up a walkthrough because these days everyone wants to be a youtube star and no one writes out walkthroughs.

Overall not a bad game.  I enjoyed the story but was glad when I was done.  I started trying to be pure stealth and not kill anyone, but it got very frustrating and I ended up going for easy kills and hiding the bodies, made it much more enjoyable.  I really don’t feel like going back and trying to get all the achievements or any finishing the side quests.
Pick it up on sale if you enjoy stealth games, otherwise don’t.

reviewText:
In terms of stealth games, this is one of the better ones that have come out in recent years.  It's a mix of Thief, Assassin's Creed, and Mark of the Ninja.  You play as a goblin attempting to infiltrate a cylindrical fortress built by a corrupt group of humans.  The execution is not as clean as one would hope, but I like the storyline and after 17 hours I'm still playing.

[PROS]
- Animations are very fluid
- Highly dependent on stealth; no beastmode stuff here
- You can bypass most of the level if you want, but completionists will have a lot to do
- Great flexibility in choosing your path and objectives.
- Finding refills of your tools in the world is VERY tricky and requires a good eye
- Good level design when it comes to canned situtations where you have to kill each guy one-by-one
- Your upgrade points are based on how many objectives you complete.  Take your time = easier gameplay.
- Whistle mechanic to attract enemies.
- Nice graphics design; enemies are one-note but you, your companions, and the world are beautiful.

[CONS]
- In terms of AI, there are a lot of times where you'll clearly be visible and the humans won't see you.
- I've also had problems with serious amounts of clipping through the environment
- Dead bodies do crazy ragdoll stuff.
- Also, their highly acclaimed goblin" mode just makes you one shot one kill
- The "skills" mechanic is very rigid.
- The voice acting leaves a lot to be desired

reviewText:
In terms of stealth games, this is one of the better ones that have come out in recent years.  It's a mix of Thief, Assassin's Creed, and Mark of the Ninja.  You play as a goblin attempting to infiltrate a cylindrical fortress built by a corrupt group of humans.  The execution is not as clean as one would hope, but I like the storyline and after 17 hours I'm still playing.

[PROS]
- Animations are very fluid
- Highly dependent on stealth; no beastmode stuff here
- You can bypass most of the level if you want, but completionists will have a lot to do
- Great flexibility in choosing your path and objectives.
- Finding refills of your tools in the world is VERY tricky and requires a good eye
- Good level design when it comes to canned situtations where you have to kill each guy one-by-one
- Your upgrade points are based on how many objectives you complete.  Take your time = easier gameplay.
- Whistle mechanic to attract enemies.
- Nice graphics design; enemies are one-note but you, your companions, and the world are beautiful.

[CONS]
- In terms of AI, there are a lot of times where you'll clearly be visible and the humans won't see you.
- I've also had problems with serious amounts of clipping through the environment
- Dead bodies do crazy ragdoll stuff.
- Also, their highly acclaimed goblin" mode just makes you one shot one kill
- The "skills" mechanic is very rigid.
- The voice acting leaves a lot to be desired

reviewText:
I wasn't really expecting much out of this game, but in the end it really surprised me with a fun, albeit hard, stealth experience. There isn't anything super original in terms of the stealth gameplay, but it's got a fun storyline that follows Styx, the worlds first goblin, in his quest to steal the heart of the worlds tree. Most of the voice acting for the NPC's isn't the best, using generic English accents and only a few lines of dialogue each, however, the voice actor for Styx is pretty good and does well with delivering Styx's sarcasm and cynicism while still sounding like the gruff old goblin that he is. The game also sports a simple yet effective upgrade system for your 3 skills: clones, invisibility and amber vision (similar to Assassins Creeds eagle vision). When going through levels there are main objectives, side objectives and insignia objectives. The first 2 are self explanatory, but the insignia objectives are where the game adds some replay value. Each level has 4 objectives that will get you bonus upgrade points: doing it without alerts, within a certain time limit, stealing all the coins and without killing anyone. This means you can go through the level and explore everywhere and find all the coins, and do it another time as fast as possible, or even try to do it fast, with no kills and no alerts. You DO NOT have to do all of them in one go, in fact it would be pretty much impossible. Once you've done the objective for that level once, you can replay it again (as many times as you want) to get the others.

CONS: The biggest and most glaring problem for me is the ledge grabbing. Where as many games will have a button to drop to a ledge, the only way to reliably drop to a ledge in this game is to slowly walk to the edge while crouched. This becomes a problem when you're trying to escape from guards as many times you will want to run towards the edge and turn around to grab it, but end up falling to your death instead
Another problem with ledges is when jumping up from either the ground or from a lower point on a wall to the uppermost point, Styx will often automatically pull himself up instead of continuing to hang from the ledge. This leads to many times where I want to jump up to a ledge and hang there until a guard passes, then pull myself up, but instead I immediately pull myself up and alert the guard instead
The combat system I'm half and half on, but I'll explain the part that irritates me about the combat system here. When going into a duel (a guard spots you and gets close enough) the game locks you into a fight with the guard. This means that when fighting multiple enemies, the others will still shoot at you and kill you while dealing with the guard you are stuck fighting. It is possible to escape the duel, but only after getting a sufficient distance away from the guard. In order to alleviate this problem, there should be a button to break out of a duel immediately, instead of clumsily trying to break out of the sequence.PROS: While that part of the combat system annoys me, I will give it credit for being there more as a fail-safe seeing as the game is stealth based, as opposed to Assassins Creed where you can win a 1v20 fight in the middle of the street without a problem. If you get spotted by a guard you have the opportunity to dispatch them then hide before backup arrives.
Shadows. This aspect of the game makes it stand out from many other stealth games, as shadows in this game DO NOT render you completely invisible. They are their as a means of cover, and makes it harder to spot you at a distance, but if a guard gets to close and spots you, he will be alerted, or at least begin noticing you.
Styx himself. The character of Styx is interesting, he has a sort of roguish charm about him, as he is incredibly sarcastic. As mentioned before the voice acting is pretty darn good for him and I've come to really like the character and the lore that surrounds him.
Last but not least, the levels. Oh my God the LEVELS. They are incredibly expansive, giving you multiple ways to reach an objective, for pretty much every objective, not just 2 but maybe even 3 or 4 or 5 ways. The quickest way may be wrought with danger, but if you keep your eyes out you may find a shortcut around the danger, or you can try to sneak your way through the most direct route, or maybe instead of sneaking, why not drop that chandelier above the guards? And while the others come to investigate, quietly make your way by them. The levels also have a lot of verticality, meaning you can climb to higher areas above the enemies, or even sneak your way below in some sewer tunnel you found. The levels are anything but linear, and allow for you to discover and explore the tower you are in.
All in all a fantastic stealth game, lots of stealth, and you get punished if you get impatient or make a wrong move, just the way a stealth game should be. I don't like number based systems of rating since there are to many aspects to fit into one number, but I would HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone who loves a solid stealth game or even RPG as the story is also pretty awesome even if it does seem cliche at the beginning ;) ( play it and you'll know what I mean). Slight ledge issues and combat aside, this game blew my mind seeing as I bought this without expecting much.

reviewText:
Solid stealth gameswith very good gameplay and multiple playstyles, but there are a few rough patches (where combat is forced). Each charpter is divided into 4 levels that function as sanfboxes you can freely navigate.Since i was trying to playthrough without being detected I didn't have parry timing down at first for these encounters, even though they are fairly easy, making these encounters a little furstrating. Some levels feel massive with many paths and optional objects, others are more closed in. The open nature of levels makes the spaces feel more real as you are not sneaking down a linear path from point A to point B, but rather navigating a castle however you please.

The game does have you replay each level, but with different entry and exit points. Additionaly, some areas/paths change and enemy placement is completely different. I find it still feels fresh. As stated earlier, levels are large and have multiple paths. Combined with the changed enemy placement and your natural development as a player (better understanding abilities and movement through the enviorment) revisting each area feels total different.

At first i felt the ability trees were rather combat focused and some branches useless, but I was just not understanding how to use my abilities. Now that I have most things unlocked ill probably chip away at 100%ing  Not sure why people complain about character movement/platforming in this game, maybe something got patched? You can play slow and methodically, exploring for alternative routes and learning guard patterns, or blitz through areas relying on your wits and abilities to keep you alive and unseen.

This game is a great deal in terms of content vs price given the quality of the gameplay. Its easily 15+ hours for a normal play through. Going non lethal pure sleath will likely take more.  While character models aren't the best, many of the enviorments look fantastic. Voice acting is not the best and lip sync in cutscenes is aweful, but the story is still interesting enough to keep me from skipping them (still, the switch from in engine cutscenes to comic book style still panels is greatly appreciated when it does take place). Given this game is not a AAA game and is not an expensive game I don't see any of the above issues being a problem

Overall, I highly recommend it to people who like sleath games, but people who want to fight when detected will be disapointed since this is a steath game, not an action game or shooter with steath elements (go play shadow of mordor). LIkely my favorite steath game since dishonored... though I can't say ive play a huge number of steath games since most things mix steath with other gameplay elements.

reviewText:
I'd give this game 8.5 out of 10, and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves infiltration.

Love it, mostly.

A few issues with overall polish, but considering it wan't a big budget game, I have to say it was extremely well done for what it is.

If there's ever a sequel, there's a few things I'd love to see changed or added:

Open world. I'd much rather play in a giant sandbox where I can go anywhere I want in the world. I don't necessarily mean 'above ground' - simply that I would have preferred to play Styx wiht the entirety of Akenash open to me at all times, rather than being limited to whatever 'level' I am currently playing.

Better AI. There's really no jump in difficulty in any of the enemies until you get to the final level and face a handful of elve (and honestly, aside from not being able to kill them, the only difficulty is in getting past them undetected). The game needs more complex behavior by the enemies - being able to take cover, seek help/backup, better abilities, etc. They really are quite dumb, and become almost tediously predictable a few levels in. The difficulty in the game only arises from the manner in which these enemies are placed, and the game becomes more about discerning the geometry of how detection works. Detection itself could be enhanced and more nuanced.

The story started off great, but felt like it got more and more rushed, almost as if the writers were suffering from fatigue, as you get to the end, and became incongruous/confusing in parts. I think this is likely due to the low budget, so I am somewhat forgiving of it - gamplay matters to me much more in a game like this, and this game has superb gameplay.

A greater variety and diversity of enemies would have been cool. The humans, dumb AI aside, were fairly diverse - there  are a number of different enemies with slightly different abilities, although it always boils down to getting caught or not. I would have liked to see a little more diversity in abilities among the humans (the frost casting knights are a good example - need more along those lines), and an overall larger bestiary. Giant spiders, baby dragons, and other nasties would have been cool to add variety to the game. The elf 'damned' (spirits) were my least favorite enemy in the game.

Still, for it's flaws, it's an incredibly value at $30 (and sometimes on sale). It took me roughly 70 hours to play, and I restarted around the third level to play it on the hardest difficulty. Definitely a good value, and I hope to see a sequel, with more polish this time.

Edit: I'm super stoked to learn that there's going to be a sequel in 2016!!! So happy about this, can't wait to see what they add.

reviewText:
Styx: Master of Shadows is a stealth game with bits of action and is described to have “RPG” elements. The game takes place in a fantasy setting set in the same universe as Of Orcs and Men. This game I believe to be the prequel to Of Orcs and Men.  Styx takes place in the Tower of Akenash. The main goal. To reach the world tree.  Seems pretty straight forward. Especially for a Goblin like creature who can stealth, scale walls, and puke up clones.

The game play itself  is very much all about playing stealthy. If you get caught there seems to be very few options you have at the start of the game but that opens up a bit through out the game as you unlock new abilities and spent skill points.  The stealth for the most part works pretty well. You can be spotted by sight or sound so it is important to not walk into buckets or furniture because you can knock them over and that makes sound. You can also walk on certain kind of surfaces that create noise. There are even lighting effects in the game that can get you caught from people seeing your shadow or just brightening and area up so they can see you. You have the options of putting out torches with your hands or using consumable balls of sand to throw at the fire from a distance. There is strategy to be had when using them as you can often use the sand on a torch to cause a distraction. You can also kill someone and use their corpse as a distraction. The stealth mechanics of the game rival that of Thief and Hitman. Hiding in closets to setup ambushes or just hiding. You can even hide the corpses of your enemies in them as well.  The stealth mechanics are some of the best of any recent stealth game available on PC.

That is where the game shines. However the combat of the game if you can call it that is just flat out horrendous. It is mostly time based parrying. Different enemies require different amounts of parry before you get the option to kill them. Almost QTE based. I often found my camera locked into confrontation and it usually led me to be killed which was extremely annoying. Again the main goal being stealth in the game. You can stealth kill people, and there are different ways of doing it but the straight head to head combat is so bad it should just be avoided at all costs. I can say I give the game props for not having INSTANT fail mechanics when being spotted but sometimes it felt like it was instant fail because of how bad the actual combat is. Getting stuck in a locked camera when fighting. Having to parry. You parry and then get whacked on by other guys while animating. It really felt like the game was broken in that aspect. Clearly your meant to not get caught.

The level design is pretty grand. Large open levels to roam around in and use as your playground. It adds variety in play. Your not stuck using this one path which I suppose can add to replay value. Either way it adds options and strategy to your game play.  In most cases there are many ways to reach your goals. That is something we all want when we play a game and not just another hallway simulator.

The game has some decent voice work and the sound work is pretty crisp.. The graphics aren’t and I say this loosely “next gen material” but they are still pretty good. There isn’t much to praise nor is there much to talk about in regards to these. They are what they are. They work. They don’t  add nor subtract from the game itself.

The story of the game is very cryptic. It’s almost a narrative but not really at the same time. Styx is being held captive and telling this story of his plan and what he was thinking. Then you see it happen / play it out. Ultimately catching up to time for the plan to come together…. We all love it when a plan comes together. It isn’t the best writing in the world but it isn’t the worst. It is nice to not always have a linear story and it often felt out of place. Then you get to that point in the story and your like…. Oohhhhhhhh!!!  Overall it was a solid story.

Styx feels more like a Thief sequel than the recent Reboot of the Thief series.  I believe that is what they were going for. The game claims to have role playing game elements. If playing a role and having skill points is role playing game elements then sure. Aside from that. Not really.  I would have loved for this game to have been an action game but it really isn’t.  I would have loved for this game to be more like Of Orcs and Men (which by the way is fantastic.) It wasn’t. It never claimed to be so I can’t hold that against them. I do hope they continue to make games in this universe and I sincerely hope they release a sequel to Of Orcs and Men in the future. Every new game the studio makes gets better and better. Learning and evolving. That is an important aspect in the gaming industry and I commend our boys over at Cyanide for that.  They are also updating the game and fixing the game based on community feedback which again is very important at this age of the industry.

In all the game isn’t ground breaking. It is listed as an action game and while I get Stealth isn’t a “legit” genre I just have all kinds of issues calling it an action game because of how bad the action itself is. I really found myself getting stuck up on that. It really brings the rest of the game down. The stealth bits of the game are fantastic but … The acti…er… Lack of is just NOT GOOD. For that we give this game….

A Drastik Measure 7.2/10   (6.0 and Higher = Reccommend)

We do think this game deserves a go. The stealth alone is really good and needs to be experienced. The price is pretty decent for only being $29.99 at launch. I would say wait for a sale but definitely pick it up and support them eventually.

As for the AI, I found it kind of spotty. Sometimes they noticed you from halfway across the map while other times they were blind when you were five feet away. A great little game.  A real diamond in the rough.  You can play it as you like, head on or in the shadows.  There are real challenges here that are satisfying when you reach the goal.

reviewText:
First impressions (because I've only completed the intro mission)

Very good. A simple explanation would be Dishonored in third person, but you're a goblin thief. Except it's much more than that.

The gameplay focuses heavily on stealth elements, and the climbing is reminiscent of Assassin's Creed. The character (Styx) can create a clone to provide distractions so you can get away safely, or you can simply become invisible to get away from a group of guards, because unlike in Assassin's Creed, Styx can't handle a full batallion of guards or so and get away completely unscathed. As such, it tells you that you need to be undetected as much as possible, though you can handle the occasional single guard or two (After reloading your save a few times, of course.). It uses the Unreal Engine, so the graphics are pretty stellar, and I've yet to find any SD textures.

I preordered the game, and it was completely worth it. I haven't had this much fun in a stealth game since I played through Dishonored, and Dishonored was amazing. The voice acting is good, and the voices fit the characters well. Though, in the game engine cutscenes the lip syncing isn't that great, but it's ignorable, and besides, the rest of the game makes you forget the lip syncing issues.

reviewText:
If you're looking for Assassin's Creed in goblin form... look somewhere else.

It's really not a bad game, but after you have experienced Assassin's Creed or some of the old Splinter Cell games it leaves some things to be desired. The stealth mechanics are not too shabby, but it's missing kill animation variety and some stealth move polishing IMO. It gets repetitive to say the least. If you get spotted, you prolly gonna die, which isn't  a bad thing since you are supposed to sneek around, silly. However, the mechanics of the toe to toe combat did not score any points with me, nor did the graphics in some parts, it was as if they just didn't really care about how some of the characters looked.

One big complement to the game however, is that it was designed with seemingly endless options for going about your stealthy business: nooks, crannies, ledges, hiding places, scalable walls, tunnles... quite impressive really. This added alot to the fun factor IMO.

So, if you havent played any of the ground breaking stealth games of this generation, I would say go ahead and pick this one up. It's fairly simple, has a good story, enough elements of good stealth play and cheesy humor to keep a younger, or perhaps more novice/naive gamer interested (just to clarify that I'm not a hater, I love cheese).

On the other hand:
If you have been keeping up with the latest and greatest of the stealth genra it's kinda like playing skyrim and then taking the first Two Worlds for a spin. Ya it's cool, kinda, ok not really. All I'm saying is that you may have a hard time turning to poorly prepared, chewy grissley carne asada after devouring a delicious FILET MIGNON! At least during the same day.

Oh, and if your very young, don't play this game cus, *stammering* cus the bad goblin says bad, bad words! Since when do mythical creatures from the middle ages spout the F word anyway? It kinda caught me off gard with that one. HAHAHAHA!

reviewText:
(Before you read my review, just because you dislike this game doesn't mean you should avoid these developer's next few games. This is the developers first type of game like this and they did a great job with scenery and character design. So I really am looking forward to the developers next few games. So even though this review sounds like I'm giving a thumbs down, I'm not. I'm just telling the developers what they should improve on, because this game isn't bad.)

Honestly, this game isn't horrible. It's just your basic stealth game. Combat isn't fun and feels unfinished. The stealth is the same everytime. Sneak up behind someone, kill them, hide behind a corner, etc. The stealth kills aren't fun like in hitman. This game you just stab someone and move on. No different ways in killing someone, you can muffle someone or just stab them..which gets very repetitive. The scenery in the game is beautiful and the character design is interesting. There's pros to this game and there's cons. Even though this game has nice scenery and interesting character design, the game lacks an interesting story. But in my opinion, for this type of game, that doesn't matter. Hitman for example has a pretty cliche' story (Hitman Absolution atleast), but is still a very fun game. Executing enemies in Hitman is very enjoyable. Well in Styx, executing enemies just gets boring, like I've said before, this game is just stab or muffle someone and move on. I really did try to enjoy this game because I saw all of the great reviews, but I really just couldn't get into this game. But, I can see why some people would enjoy this game. Also let me just say, this is the developers first time making a game like this. And honestly this game isn't bad, just repetitive. So I honestly can't wait to see how the developers will improve on their next few games.

What you just read sounds like a bad review. But it's not. This review says not recommended, but that does not mean this game is bad. I just didn't really get into the stealth/combat, plus this is just some things the developers can improve on.

6/10

reviewText:
Whew, so this game was kind of a struggle to the finish for me. I did beat it though.

Styx: Master of shadows has you playing a goblin in a stealth action setting similar to thief except minus the stealing things part and plus a lot to murdering everything. The storyline is interesting and the devs do a good job with pushing the narriative along which is mainly what got me through the whole game. Also the MC has a very tongue-in-cheek sarcastic view of the world and the dialogue/monologue has it's own brand of dark humor.

The stealth element of the game is absolutely central to the gameplay to the point where if you are discovered your chance of survival is very low especially if it's by two or more enemies. Normally in most stealth games this is not much of a problem because enemies are spaced out and have non-overlapping patrols, but in this game you will find areas to be VERY crowded, making traditional duck and weave navigation somewhat problematic. One of the mechanics, cloning (in which you make a duplicate of yourself with limited abilities) assists with this somewhat and even offers the chance when upgraded to set lethal traps for enemies. However, I found myself using it most of the time just to alert guards and get them to chase it so that I could pass areas in a reasonable amount of time. Most of the other abilities are somewhat useless. Invisibility costs A LOT of amber to use and only lasts a short while, and the combat skills are really only useful in 1v1 situations and don't help against hardened enemies like the knights or elves. So basically, you either pull entire rooms using your clone (easy & fast) or try and systematically eliminate targets until the way is clear (very very slow/difficult). Overall though, the crowdedness makes it a pain in the ♥♥♥ to stealth missions.

Speaking of the enemies, the AI is very quirky and patrols seem very easy to glitch. Sometimes a path that an enemy takes 3 times in a row suddenly differs on the 4th for no apparent reason. I would think this is a feature except it also does things like teleport around during alerts and some enemies will even get stuck in corners or between objects indefinitely (for no reason!).

The levels in this game are pretty huge, which seems like a truly impressive feat at first until you realize you spend the second half of the game backtracking all the way through them which I found to be kind of boring and a bit lazy design-wise. That being said, the overall design is nice and I would enjoy them more if it weren't for the last beef I have with this game: the controls.

Controlling your character in this game can be a literal nightmare if you decide to go running around in high places. Targeted jumps to wall sconces work maybe 80% of the time and if you don't have your camera and directional tilted the exact way you will miss by a fair margin. Performing safe falls (e.g. lowering yourself until you are hanging by your hands and then dropping) is almost entirely guesswork and you may find yourself accidentally climbing all the way back up, potentially exposing yourself to danger. Also the corner turning is very awkward and the corner kill feature isn't very obvious as to what distance you can do it at (more guesswork). Simply put, the controls for this game, while adequate, can be frustrating as hell in tense situations where every second matters.

Anyways, I _would_ recommend this game to someone if the devs were to fix the majority of my abovementioned gripes. Maybe even a fan-made patch could do it. In its current state though, I would recommend giving it a pass unless you are a die-hard fan of stealth games.

reviewText:
Check out my fully detailed review here.[uncrownedreview.blogspot.com]

The entire game is riddled with problems.

First, elves. These are enemies you can only kill with throwing knives or aerial attacks as they detect you based on distance rather than on anything you've learned to avoid up to that point. They appear at the very end of the game meaning you have no controlled environment to learn how to kill them, and aerial attacks are locked behind a skill. So one of your only two methods of dealing with them is locked away for... reasons?

Second, every enemy in the game. The AI is just terrible. There are times when I placed a clone in a chest and whistled from the other side of the room. Where does the enemy look for the source of the noise? Well obviously the chest! The chest 10 meters away from the whistling. Because logic. And that's when they're not walking into each other, messing up their patrol routes and making it impossible to sneak past them without invisibility or slaughter.

Third, the controls. Everything in this game is extremely finnicky. Some of the jumps you have to make are obstructed by objects over your head that you can't avoid. You just have to hope that Styx understands from your instructions to avoid smashing his head into the chandlier. Sometimes he will, sometimes he'll fall to the ground and get tramped by guards. It's also up to luck whether or not you'll pull off things like aerial assaults or covered kills in certain areas.

Fourth, there are very few autosave points per level. And considering how finnicky a lot of the controls and jumps can be in this game that means you're going to die and go right back to the start of the level a lot. It's a little sad when Half Life Source has better autosave than a game released in this modern age.

Finally, the final boss is disappointingly pathetic. As in the only way they could think of to ramp up the difficulty was to make the final boss near impossible without a full bar of amber plus several amber potions. Yes, it's that type of boss. Not a boss that tests everything we've learned and used up to that point but a boss that ramps up the difficulty by being a specific type of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t while you play the adventure game logic of figuring out how the developers wanted you to beat this guy. It's frustrating to the point that I'm almost certain most of the reviewers giving this a high score never actually played the game to completion before giving it their glowing recommendation. It's worth docking 2-3 points off any score for.

Instead of a score I'll just say this. Styx: Master of Shadows is worth around $15.00 USD. There's enough to like about the game to enjoy it if you get it at that price but not anything close to the base price.

reviewText:
I did not have high expectations going into this game but I was dissapointed none the less...   In the games defense, I played it a year after release & paid very little for it in a sale.  I would of been extremely upset to have paid full price.

Styx does not do anything particularly well.  I cannot say it really has 1 redeeming quality.  The visuals are shoddy with bad textures.  The sound & music is average, along with shocking (with the exception of the main character) voice acting.

I like stealth games but this really just did not work.  The entire game is a series of fail and retry attempts strung together by a loading screen.  Thank god I was running on an SSD as the loading times were very short.  If you are seen you may as well pause & reload checkpoint. there is an option to engage in direct combat but the duel" system is terrible. More than one enemy? Forget it. Reload that checkpoint.

Luckily you can save at any point and you will need to.  The platforming controls compound the frustration with multiple deaths from irritating falls from ledges you should of grabbed hold of etc.  So expect many deaths.

My play time was around 18 hours and by the half way point I really just wanted it to be over.  The story is forgettable and I did not care what happened to any of the characters involved.  The game starts adding a few different enemy types later on but these just prove to be even more frustrating as they are impervous to various means of incipacitation.

There is a very rudimentary upgrade system that allows you to spend points earned in missions on skill upgrades but I really only found myself using the same 2 over and over.

So sadly I cannot recommend this
date: even to fans of the genre.  Spend your time & money elsewhere.\n\nPeace x"

reviewText:
I wanted to love this game so much because it has a beautiful world, great gameplay style, good ambient sound... it does a lot of things right.  But it's marred by a thousand small issues that make it a pain to play.  It sucks but these issues make the game more bothersome than its worth, at least to me.  For example, there are times when you are met with a challenge, and something glitches so that you can't do what you want.  Some of the hideouts in the game are inaccessible because of poor hitbox placement.  It kills me when I see small bugs like that ruining my gameplay experience.  Another issue that irks me is sometimes an enemy will stumble upon a fallen comrade and slip into a nonstop loop of calling for help.  It's funny the first few times but it did start to bother me after a while.

I've had issues where I kill an enemy in just the right spot for me to do it stealthily, then when the kill is done, the guy's body glitches and flings itself a few feet forward, warning all the people in the room of my presence and ruining my careful plots.  In a stealth game, I love trying to plan my route and carefully kill targets, but glitches like this destroy the experience for me.  I don't know whether this game was rushed at the end of development or if the devs just didn't care to clean up the bugs.  Either way, it's *just* enough of a problem that I'm going to stop playing.

If you can deal with issues like these, please play this game.  It's a wonderful experience.  I just can't handle it the way it is right now.

reviewText:
I'm a fan of stealth games, being somewhat patient and never one to run and gun.  Styx: Master of Shadows is an enjoyable stealth game for the price.  What I like about it is the sense of it being different: you are a goblin in a world of men; not a second class or even a third class citizen: you are a monster.  And yet Styx, the protagonist, is not the evil creature that goblins are so often portrayed as in common fantasy...he is an anti-hero, but not vile.

I liked the style of the game: the castle settings are very intricate: it's a maze of tunnels, stairways, balconies, ledges, etc...if you like climbing and skulking and choosing the best path, you will enjoy this game.
I found the stealth mechanic to be fairly balanced...you have to be careful: they will see you if you are too close, even if it is in the shadows, so you reallly have to time your movements...and if you kick over a bucket, you will arouse suspicion and the guards will quickly investigate.

If you are looking for Assassin's Creed combat, you will not find it here, in the least...combat is about timing your parries to block strikes from the guards; if you do it poorly, the hits will take a massive chunk of heath out.  If you do it well, and block two parries, this will unbalance" the guard and your next move will be a simple kill move (at least in the beginning levels).

Two words: avoid combat.  You will live longer.

reviewText:
I'm a fan of stealth games, being somewhat patient and never one to run and gun.  Styx: Master of Shadows is an enjoyable stealth game for the price.  What I like about it is the sense of it being different: you are a goblin in a world of men; not a second class or even a third class citizen: you are a monster.  And yet Styx, the protagonist, is not the evil creature that goblins are so often portrayed as in common fantasy...he is an anti-hero, but not vile.

I liked the style of the game: the castle settings are very intricate: it's a maze of tunnels, stairways, balconies, ledges, etc...if you like climbing and skulking and choosing the best path, you will enjoy this game.
I found the stealth mechanic to be fairly balanced...you have to be careful: they will see you if you are too close, even if it is in the shadows, so you reallly have to time your movements...and if you kick over a bucket, you will arouse suspicion and the guards will quickly investigate.

If you are looking for Assassin's Creed combat, you will not find it here, in the least...combat is about timing your parries to block strikes from the guards; if you do it poorly, the hits will take a massive chunk of heath out.  If you do it well, and block two parries, this will unbalance" the guard and your next move will be a simple kill move (at least in the beginning levels).

Two words: avoid combat.  You will live longer.

Styx: Master of Shadows is one of the great games in the stealth genre, that unlike popular main stream games like Assassin's Creed, take away the brawling option from your playthrough and makes you use stealth and strategy to get through the level. This is game-breaking. Not all players will experience it, but obviously, you don't want to get stuck an hour or so into the game, having only completed the first mission.

I can't endorse this game for this reason, and would advice you strongly against buying it.

reviewText:
Not only has Cyanide Studio been the sole provider of proper Games Workshop Studio properties, after their CEO (Games Workshop) went nutters and gave the license to nearly everyone with a buck and a development team after Relic (RIP you glorious ♥♥♥♥ers) went under, they've taken the ball and not only rolled with it to it's natural RPG conclusion, but have excelled at it.

Of Orcs and Men, where you are first introduced to Styx and the mythology they've established, is a welcomed breath of air (in a stale monogamous relationship of mechanics that are supposed to mirror story, that is the current character driven action adventure of copy paste)

Styx is a story told in a 3D world in which you are free to move in any typical action-character game, however what sets this apart is the experience given by Cyanyde Studios from their previous (and held in high esteem with this reviewer's opinion) games - Namely, Game of Thrones & Of Orcs and Men - that focus (and streght that carries) on the character instead of the mechanics.

Styx is a goblin. Possibly the worst goblin and only goblin, Not only is he (possibly) the only goblin, but he like us were created without seeming purpose, and the search for said purpose is the main drive - and proper plot - of this story.

While the gameplay mechanics reinforce the frailty of our shorter-than-short protagonist (antagonist?) is the main selling point, what really drives this game home, is the EXCELLENT writring by Cyanide, that has proven time and time again that they can make a true character driven game - aside from their yearly pro-cycling installment (which by the way, also is hallmark)

You are the assassin Styx, through and through, which is a rare thing to say these days.

Cyanide has come a long way since the '12 installment of Game of Thrones (which again, was a really good story for Fans of the series) and they show no sign of stopping.

Personally, I could do with more stories from the ultra-cynical-only-out-for-himself-trick-or-die-goblin Styx, and maybe if we're lucky. the Bloodjaw clan.


Make no mistake however, these games are - unlike the Telltale Games variant which might be classified as interactive novels - full-blown video game (camera over) shoulder to shoulder, and I could not be happier about that fact.

This is a great first game in the series. I havent played that much yet but enough to know i like it. Interesting maps with lots of options, and good gameplay. The only thing i dont like is the combat lock. I can understand they didnt want to make things to easy, but it feels like a very strange mechanic. Basically once discovered and engaged you cant run away, well as good as. Instead, you get to die. Its not a game killer, and is a very deliberate mechanic to force you to be careful. No run and 'gun' assassin's creed chicken running here. So for a game that kills you alot, random guard positioning would also have been nice to keep things fresh on that 3rd run through. Maybe next time.

Dispite this being a list of things i dont like, i do like this game overall and would recommend it to stealth fans.

Solid buy if bought in a sale, now often being offered at 60% off. On the strength of this i will definately be buying Styx 2 if/when it comes out.

reviewText:
There is not much stealth games for PC, and only very few good ones. I'm glad that Styx just sticks to good old stealth mechanics and it definitely reached it's only goal - to be a good stealth game.

Styx brings very classic stealth mechanics with few inovations. You can perform several types of stealth kills, you can hide dead bodies into closets, chests, etc, if you see the guard pee-sing (anticensor :D ) from the edge of the rampart, you can actualy kick him down :)
In adition to conventional mechanics known from similar games, Styx comes with kinda RPG element - you can improve your skills, so you can kill your enemies by more effective ways.....or you can choose to be a merciful kind thief and let everyone live :)

If you like stealth games, and you loved games like Tenchu, MGS and Splinter Cell, Styx definitely worth a try :)

reviewText:
Styx is a good game. One that could have been a Great sneaker, but sadly falls short in a few areas.

Pick it up on sale though and it's well worth it.

The level designs are some of the best I've seen, they are very large (especially for the genre) and very 3D, many you simply cannot do if you think only in 2 dimensions.

Many reviews point to the combat system as the main weakness.. but that is tosh... you are a goblin, small and not strong compared to humans, you are supposed to die fast if you are caught! This is not assasins creed where you can take on 20+ men and merrily slash you way through then blend in" to the crowd to escape! You can maybe fight of 2 people and do a runner... maybe... but the point is to be a "master of shadows" and not get caught! If you are fighting you are playing wrong!

The 2 main issues are the AI and the characterr movement
